title: 'Black widow serial killer' accused of poisoning husband and in-laws with cyanide

A "black widow" is accused of murdering her husband and five in-laws with cyanide that was mixed into their soups, snacks and medicinal drinks.

Alleged serial killer Jolly Joseph, 47, slowly poisoned her family members in a twisted plot to inherit money and a house, according to police.

She allegedly confessed to the killings, which took place over a 14-year period, after being arrested in a sleepy village this month in a case that has gripped India and is already being turned into a film.

Churchgoing Joseph, who has two sons, is said to have told detectives that she was fascinated by death and took pleasure in watching the final moments of the six victims, including a two-year-old girl.

She is accused of killing her mother-in-law, Annamma Thomas, 57, in 2002, her father-in-law, Tom Thomas, 66, in 2008 and her husband, Roy Thomas, 40, in 2011.

It is claimed she also confessed to murdering her husband's 67-year-old uncle, Mathew Manjadiyil, in 2014, his cousin's 44-year-old wife, Sily Shaju, in 2016, and Mrs Shaju's two-year-old daughter Alphine in 2014.

After allegedly killing Mrs Shaju, Jolly - once regarded as a "model" wife and daughter-in-law - married the victim's husband (her late husband's cousin).

Indian media have called her a "black widow" and the case in the village of Koodathayai, Kerala, has been dubbed the "Jolly Murders".

Local police have gone as far as comparing her to "Dr Death" Harold Shipman, the British GP jailed for murdering 15 patients but suspected of killing as many as 250 before he was caught.

The serial killer, who died by suicide in prison after being jailed for life, gave his victims lethal injections of diamorphine.

In the "Jolly Murders", the victims' bodies have been exhumed for forensic examinations.

Renji Thomas, the sister of Joseph's first husband, told the New York Times: "I just pray that we can bring my family members justice.

"You don’t know what it does to me as a daughter, as a sister, to see my loved ones’ remains after so long, taken from their graves."

Police said they have seized a bottle that allegedly contained cyanide used to kill Joseph's family members.

It was found in the kitchen of a home, it is claimed.

Detectives also claim that Joseph often carried cyanide in her bag and made made "meticulous planning" to carry out and conceal each murder.

Villagers have questioned whether police could have stopped the alleged killer earlier on and prevented additional deaths.

The death of her mother-in-law, a retired teacher, was treated as a natural death, while the death of her father-in-law, a government employee, was ruled heart failure.

Joseph's husband died a similar death, but the post-mortem report revealed he had been poisoned with cyanide, it was reported.

Her husband's uncle died similarly, and his daughter died of a heart attack.

Joseph, who falsely claimed to be a university lecturer in conversations with other villagers, married Mrs Shaju's husband in 2017 and claimed ownership of the family property.

Her alleged crimes were revealed after Rojo Thomas - her first husband's brother - urged police to reopen their investigations into the deaths based on his own suspicions.

Joseph, who faces six counts of premeditated murder, was denied bail when she appeared in court on Saturday.

Two men accused of supplying the cyanide have also been arrested.
description: Jolly Joseph, 47, was fascinated by death and took pleasure as she killed her husband, his parents and three extended family members by mixing cyanide into their food and drinks, say police
